utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Then why is--

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: But the President has made it clear that he would--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --she leaving?

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: --she was leaving, Tucker, as you know, as you have reported because she was going to Brussels to meet with our NATO officials, and she was going to Afghanistan to thank our men and women in uniform.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: To thank our troops.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: I don't know how many times we have to say it-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right. But in the middle of a--

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: --and go back and forth to that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --government shutdown that you say is hurting people, but she doesn't want to stay and negotiate it because she needs to "Thank our troops?"

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: She has absolutely stayed, and she's worked with this President on multiple occasions. He got up from the table and he left the Office the last time that they sat down--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. But - but I guess my point is - I mean, look, as an adult--

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: --to have a negotiation, that is on him.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --as an adult question, why would she be mad about this? It probably is fair actually she should stay. This isn't helping anybody, this shut down. I mean it. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: No, it's not helping anyone.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Why not just stay and figure it out? OK. So, now, she had this bad idea to go to Afghanistan to thank our troops, who are serving in a war that she's not sure whether she supports or not. But why not just stay here and--

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: This is so pointless.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, it's not.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: This is--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, it's totally real.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: --no, it - it is real. But it's - it's - it's annoying to me because we're sitting here talking about a woman taking a trip. She's not going now. So, we can all really just get over it. What I would really like to know is-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: --when this President is going to sit down with the Democrats and re-open the government for the people that are not getting paid.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well I guess now we put--

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: People that I know personally.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --well that's a fair quest - that's a fair question.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: People that I care about that are not--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, I know. Right, right, I know. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: --getting their paychecks.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I live here too. So, isn't this a good thing? I'm not sure why you're complaining about it. Now, he can sit down with Nancy Pelosi because he's prevented her from leaving the country. So, why wouldn't you applaud this?

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: I don't applaud it because he did it as a tit-for-tat. He's immature. That's why he did it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But you - but you're happy about the outcome but you don't like his motives.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: I don't - no, I definitely don't like his motives at all. I think that his motivations are to build a wall that is pretty much, instead of saying Make America Great Again, he might as well say to Mexico, "If you're Brown, turnaround." That's what the message is.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. I think you may have gotten your talking points confused. But I - I appreciate your--

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: No talking points. Straight conversation. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --mustering the, you know, (ph) talking points. Yes, you just made that up on the flood (ph). Brilliant!

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Rochelle, thank you.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: I'm that good.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Good to see you tonight.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well as the federal shutdown continues, Democrats have coalesced around a rationale for their continued opposition to a Border wall. They're no longer telling you that walls are too expensive. That was a laughable argument coming from the Left, so they've given up. They're not telling you that walls don't work because, obviously, they do. Everybody knows that. The problem, they are now telling us, and you just heard it, is that God doesn't like walls. They're immoral. As Beto O'Rourke, noted the other day, walls "Ensure death." Building a wall is the same as committing murder. Well Democrat Ilhan Omar of Minnesota has been in Congress for only a matter of weeks. But already, she strongly agrees with this.

utterances.speaker: REP. ILHAN ABDULLAHI OMAR, D-MINN.
utterances.sentences: And I demand that the President end his temper tantrums and quest for a racist and sinful big wall.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Racist and xenophobic. That's what walls are. And once you understand that, it does make you think there are an awful lot of walls in this country. Now that we know that they're an offense against God, how can we let them stand? Well that's a real question for the city of El Paso, Texas. El Paso is on the border, right across from Juarez, Mexico. El Paso is a calm and peaceful and pretty city. It's a great place. Juarez is violent and chaotic. It's one of the most dangerous cities in the world. How can these two places exist side by side? Well, simple. There's a wall between them. Congresswoman Veronica Escobar now represents the City of El Paso. She just replaced Beto O'Rourke. Escobar says it may be time to knock down that sinful wall.

utterances.speaker: REP. VERONICA ESCOBAR, D-TX
utterances.sentences: We know that walls don't work, that they don't stop drugs, that they don't stop migration.

utterances.speaker: JOHN BERMAN, CNN NEW DAY CO-ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: El Paso has a wall. You say it doesn't work. Would you ever call for the removal of the wall there?

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: You know, I - I - it's - it's really ugly. It - it - it is, I think, a monument to division. We've always had fencing along the U.S.- Mexico border. It's existed. I'm a lifelong resident. It always was there. But the bigger and taller and uglier that they get, they really just become symbols.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: A monument to division. That's what El Paso's new Congresswoman calls her city's wall. And she's right, by the way. Walls do divide. That's the point of having them. There are some things people would like to be divided from, like endemic corruption and murderous drug cartels. How do you accomplish that without walls? Well Nancy Pelosi has been thinking about this recently. Here's her solution.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF., SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE
utterances.sentences: And then we talk about technology. As I said, several hundred million dollars, ranges from a half a billion to $700 million for the technology to scan the cars coming through the ports of entry. And that is to detect guns. It's like an electronic dog almost to - to detect drugs, guns and other contraband.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: An electronic dog, of course. How obvious? It was right there in plain sight, and we missed it. The rest of us were thinking about security in old-fashioned medieval terms, walls, fences, actual living dogs. But leave it to the Congresswoman from our Technology Capital out in California to think a lot bigger than that. You're looking at the solution of the future, an electronic dog. Brilliant! This show has exclusively obtained a prototype of the Speaker's digital canine. You're watching it right now. Just kidding! We pulled that off the internet, probably not so different from the real thing though. We'll see. In the meantime though, let's take Nancy Pelosi and Beto O'Rourke, and the entire editorial staffs on the other cable channels seriously for a moment. Let's concede that walls are, in fact, inherently immoral. How do we respond once we've accepted that? We can't simply prevent Donald Trump from building a wall. That's not enough. We've got to do something about the countless walls of wickedness that degrade and pollute America's moral landscape. For example, the wall that keeps poor people out of Barack Obama's home in Washington, the wall that protects George Soros' placed in South Hampton, the wall at the Pelosi compound in Napa, not to mention the wall around Mark Zuckerberg's estate in Hawaii, the gated communities of Brentwood, the walled gardens of Brooklyn. Level them all, all of them. Make them flat. In fact, do it tonight before an angry God turns us all to pillars of salt for ignoring his anti-Wall commandment. "Speaker Pelosi, tear down these walls." Once you've done that, turn the bulldozer of righteousness outward to the world. Israel, for example, surrounded by walls on virtually all sides. Does Nancy Pelosi know that? Will she withhold billions in military aid until those walls are gone? That's a moral question now. What's the answer? And how about Tunisia and Jordan? We helped pay for those country's walls. We are implicated in those walls. Will we pay to take them down? How much do we really care about our souls? We contacted the Speaker today to find out. She didn't reply. Neither did the other Democrats we called. It turns out they have no plans to eliminate anyone else's walls, and certainly not their own. They just don't want (ph) a wall that protect America. They don't think our country deserves that. Just yesterday, The New York Times ran a piece by a man called Farhad Manjoo. He demanded that the U.S. get rid of its borders entirely. No borders. If 10 million, a 100 million, a billion people want to move here, so be it. It's not our right to keep them out. It's only our obligation to pay for it. That's the Democrats' position. They're telling us that God agrees with them. Mark Morgan was the Head of the Border Patrol under President Obama, and he joins us tonight. Mr. Morgan, thanks very much for coming on.

utterances.speaker: MARK MORGAN, FORMER BORDER PATROL CHIEF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, to the new Congresswoman, Congresswoman Escobar from El Paso, I think it's a fair question. What would happen, since walls are immoral, if we removed the wall that separates El Paso, a great city, from Juarez, Mexico?

utterances.speaker: MORGAN
utterances.sentences: We - we would take a huge step backwards. Again, I - I lived and worked in El Paso for two years.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MORGAN
utterances.sentences: And the drug cartels, we were able to almost eliminate the avenues that they had for all the things we've talked about before, drugs, human trafficking, illegal trafficking as well. And but - by doing that, by building the walls, we increased the Border Patrol's operational capability and stance, to more effectively respond and stop those bad things and bad people from coming in. Nancy Pelosi, I agree with her, the ports of entry, absolutely. By building the wall, for example, in El Paso, what that did was increase the Border Patrol's operational capability. And it cut off that avenue, and it then funneled (ph) people to the ports of entry, where we stand a better chance of interdicting.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: What's so interesting in El Paso, which, as you've said, had a wall, you lived there, is be - Democrats want to make everything about border security a racial question. And you heard a guest we just had saying you're racist if you're for a wall. There is a wall separating El Paso from the disaster right across the border. El Paso is, I think, is a 80 percent Hispanic. It's not a city, I've been there many times, as noted for racial tension, so people of the same ethnicity living in the United States are supporting a wall, and they're sort of happy to live there. So like, there's no inherent racial component to any of this unless I'm missing something. Is there?

utterances.speaker: MORGAN
utterances.sentences: No. And it - it's - it's even more outrageous than that from my opinion. So, instead of opinion, let's look at fact. And the fact is Yuma County Sheriff just got on this week, and he talked about, during his time there, his deputies found and recovered over a 100 bodies of people trying to illegally enter the country that died of exposure and other issues. We - we just heard tragic deaths of two kids, two children that died. They didn't die from the hands of Americans law enforcement. They died at the hands of the coyote making the perilous trek without medical attention and - and without nutrition. And Unites States Border Patrol, not hundreds, but they execute thousands of rescues every single year of illegal aliens trying to enter the country, in between the points of entry. The Wall takes that avenue away. So, the very people that - that are saying the rhetoric out there is actually strengthening the cartels' hold in the Southern border, which is actually doing harm and exploiting the very people that they say they want to protect.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well because bad people thrive in chaos. And what we have now is chaos. So, but when you hear Beto O'Rourke say, "Constructing the wall will cause people to die. It is an act of murder to construct a wall," how do you respond to that?

utterances.speaker: MORGAN
utterances.sentences: It - it's - it - it's almost impossible to - to respond to that because it's not based in reality, and it's not based on fact. I, again, they're not listening to the experts. They just - just totally discount when the - when the Sheriff at Yuma County that's done this his entire life said, "We recovered a 100 dead bodies." How - how does Beto - Beto then - then say that - that the wall kills people? It's absolutely false.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That we kill people, amazing!

utterances.speaker: MORGAN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Mark Morgan, thank you very much for joining us tonight. I appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: MORGAN
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well a magazine here in Washington says it is time to impeach the President for general badness, calls upon the Congress to do that. Mark Steyn read the piece. He's digested it, and he'll respond after the break.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well The Atlantic magazine, which used to be good before it became rigid, and inflexible, and humorless, and stupid, and uninteresting, is leading its latest issue, the March issue with a piece calling on the Congress to impeach the President just because he's a bad guy. Plenty of Democrats already agree with this. They've been demanding impeachment for quite a while now.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTOPHER LOFFREDO HAYES, ALL IN WITH CHRIS HAYES HOST, MSNBC
utterances.sentences: Do you still think the President should be impeached?

utterances.speaker: REP. RASHIDA HARBI TLAIB, D-MICH.
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: REP. ALEXANDER N. GREEN, D-TX
utterances.sentences: Impeachment is not dead. One step closer to impeachment. Yesterday's resolution brought us one step closer.

utterances.speaker: THOMAS FAHR STEYER, DEMOCRATIC FUNDRAISER
utterances.sentences: I will be dedicating 100 percent of my time, effort, and resources to one cause, working for Mr. Trump's impeachment, and removal from Office.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Tom Steyer, ladies and gentlemen. He's a much better person than you are. And he's been calling for impeachment for a long time. But during the 2018 midterm campaign, Democrats tried their best to mute that message. Their leaders told the base, "Be quiet. Shh. You don't want to scare people. No more talking about impeachment. We believe in democratic solutions to leaders we don't like." They're still saying that sort of in public. But will they be able to keep the impeachment enthusiasts in their party under control? Huh. That's the question. Mark Steyn has been thinking about this quite a bit, and he joins us tonight. So, Mark, what do you - what did you make this - since you're a long time, long time magazine writer, you read this piece. What - what did you make of the argument it made for impeachment?

utterances.speaker: MARK STEYN, AUTHOR, COLUMNIST, STEYNONLINE.COM
utterances.sentences: Well, first of all, I agree with your assessment of the present diminished state of The Atlantic Monthly. And you said I was a magazine writer. I used to write for The Atlantic a decade or so back. And I'm not saying I'm one of their Giants, when you go back through the years. But they've had Mark Twain and Lord Moulton, and all kinds of great people--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: --writing for them. This thing goes wrong right from under the - the sub headline. Starting the process of impeachment will reign in a President, who is undermining American ideals, and bring the debate about his fitness for Office into Congress where it belongs. Actually, American ideals, American values, however you want to phrase it, those transcendental values, they are the province of the people.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: And that is the prerogative of the people, not of bureaucrats and administrators, and the pseudo-judicial process in Washington. And, as for the debate about his fitness, bringing it in to him about his fitness for Office into Congress, where it belongs, no, that too, his fitness for office, that too is in the gift of the people. And we're teaching a very dangerous lesson here. Basically, they're - they're - they're not disputing that Trump was elected according to the lawful mechanisms of elections in the United States. What they're saying is they don't like the result of that election. And you're teaching the people a very dangerous lesson there. You're saying that voting doesn't matter and, in - in essence, thereby setting in motion, essentially, revolutionary conditions, if you tell people in a free society that your vote doesn't matter.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I think you're absolutely right. And I think that there are leaders on the Democratic side who sense that what you're saying is right. And there could - they could be unleashing forces they can't control, and they might be hurting themselves.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: What do you think would happen--

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --politically, if impeachment commenced?

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Oh, I think it - I think it would be an absolute fiasco. I mean one of the most deplorable trends in this country in the last few years is the attempt to actually criminalize opposition. Basically, this - this guy's piece is written in a kind of pseudo-scholarly, pseudo-judicial form. But it's full of what lawyers would call conclusory allegations that you're not actually allowed to make in a - a legal complaint. He uses - you called it general badness. He accuses Trump of attacking the bedrock of American democracy. Well, you know, that's this - that's kind of fancy writing. But what does that actually mean? There is not a - there is no bedrock of American democracy. It's not down there by the fence in El Paso, and you take a pickaxe to it. You can't actually litigate that. You can revile this President. You can loathe this President.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: But Robert Mueller has been investigating him for two years, and has come up empty, except for Papadopoulos lying about a cocktail he had with the Australian High Commissioner to the United Kingdom in a bar in London. That's - that's after two years of this rubbish.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It was a very dangerous cocktail though. Mark Steyn, put it better than anyone I know. Thank you. Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well Syria isn't the only military commitment America has abroad right now. Or - our largest 14,000 troops remain in Afghanistan. There are reports the President is considering withdrawing some or all of them. Is that wise? What should our policy toward Afghanistan be? And how does it affect our contest with China, our biggest rival? Robert Kaplan has been more places than anyone I'm aware of. He's a Senior Fellow at the Center for the New American Security, and he joins us tonight. Mr. Kaplan, thank you very much for coming on.

utterances.speaker: ROBERT KAPLAN, CENTER FOR A NEW AMERICAN SECURITY SENIOR FELLOW
utterances.sentences: It's my pleasure to be here.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, you've written about Afghanistan, thought about Afghanistan, a lot about Afghanistan. In your judgment, what's the right course going forward in Afghanistan?

utterances.speaker: KAPLAN
utterances.sentences: Well, first of all, let's lay out some facts. The United States has been in Afghanistan for 17 years. The troops being deployed there now were in diapers, literally, when we first went in in October 2001. We have no chance to militarily defeat the Taliban. And we have little chance to leave behind either a self-sustaining democracy or even a self- sustaining, very well-functioning, enlightened dictatorship. All the trend lines are bad, it seems, unfortunately. And what we're sustaining at the moment is a moderate level of chaos where warlords, ethnic groups compete with each other. And if we pulled out, unfortunately, there would be a much greater level of chaos. And, in fact, the regime might actually collapse in the way that the Saigon regime collapsed--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: KAPLAN
utterances.sentences: --in 1975. Therefore, either this President or the next President, whoever, is going to face the choice of how to pull out of Afghanistan, because the terrorist threat is still there. But the question becomes, is spending $45 billion a year there the right way to deal with international terrorism, because the Iranians, the Indians, the Pakistanis, the Chinese, all have strong strategic interests in Afghanistan. We do not our strategic interests there, and it's complicated to explain. We don't have time now or--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: KAPLAN
utterances.sentences: --much, much less. So, we're going to have to pull out under this President or the next one.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, what you just said sounds right. And it sounds like it's probably a conclusion that's been clear for a while. What does it say about our policymakers here in Washington that nobody is, that I'm aware of, is debating this at a high level in public anyway, and that this has been allowed to persist in this kind of counterproductive limbo for so long?

utterances.speaker: KAPLAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. This is a classic case of where many people in Washington, many thoughtful people know what needs to be done, but nobody dares utter it. Remember, Afghanistan is not Syria. Syria, you don't have Gold Star families where we've had--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: KAPLAN
utterances.sentences: --2,300 soldiers killed as we've had in Afghanistan. You don't have very esteemed Generals reputations built around Syria, whereas in Afghanistan, we've had a number of very senior esteemed famous Generals who've been Commanders there. Pulling out of Afghanistan would be politically much more difficult, I believe, for this President or any President than pulling out of Syria.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: KAPLAN
utterances.sentences: Pulling out of Syria domestically, politically, is a Washington debate more or less. Pulling out of Afghanistan may become a national debate.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I think that's right. Mr. Kaplan, thank you very much for coming on and explaining that. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: KAPLAN
utterances.sentences: My pleasure.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well a prominent House Democrat, it's hard to believe this but, is accused tonight of firing a staff member after that staff member made an allegation of rape. Amazing! We've got details after the break.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Pretty amazing story that's not getting enough attention tonight. A House Democratic staffer is suing a Democratic Member of Congress. The staffer said she was fired for making an allegation of rape. Fox Correspondent, David Spunt, is on this story for us tonight. David?

utterances.speaker: DAVID SPUNT, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, Tucker, as you were saying, well disturbing allegations coming from a former employee of longtime Texas Congresswoman, Sheila Jackson Lee. This former employee claims that she was raped by a former Congressional Black Caucus Foundation employee, and was fired by Jackson Lee's office after the employee planned to sue. The former Jackson Lee staffer named Jane Doe in a lawsuit filed just last Friday says a former Intern Coordinator for the Caucus Foundation named a man named Damien Jones, she's saying that he raped her in 2015. Jane Doe says that Jones was her Supervisor at the time. Doe reported the alleged rape to authorities. But the investigation was inconclusive when it came to evidence, well when she went to tell authorities. Fast forward to 2017, Jane Doe took a job with Congresswoman Jackson Lee out of Texas, who became Chair of the Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, Jane Doe found out that Damien Jones was also going to be working with her again, and she reported to authorities that she had a prior situation with him. Now, Jane Doe says that she repeatedly reached out to Congresswoman Jackson Lee who would not meet her. Now, to be clear, we reached out to Damien Jones mentioned in this lawsuit for comment, but we have not heard back. We do though, Tucker, have a statement from Congresswoman Jackson Lee's office. I want to read it in part. It says, "The office adamantly denies the allegations that it retaliated against, or otherwise improperly treated, the Plaintiff. It is against office policy to discuss specific details about internal personnel matters. Congresswoman Jackson Lee has an outstanding record of supporting civil rights and non-discrimination, both in legislation and in her own office." Now the statement goes on to say that Jackson Lee, when she came to Congress in 1995, was a strong supporter of the Congressional Accountability Act, which protects Congressional employees. The statement also says, Tucker, that Jackson Lee is confident that when the facts come to light, her office will be exonerated and the matter will be put to rest. Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Her defense? I'm a good person. David Spunt, thank you very much for that.

utterances.speaker: SPUNT
utterances.sentences: You bet, thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.sentences: DRUGGED.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well as America's opioid epidemic continues, in some ways, worsens, a new feature is coming to a decaying metropolis near you. It's called a safe injection site. So, rather than help addicts get off drugs, many cities are trying to create publicly-funded areas where addicts can shoot drugs intravenously, legally. Denver just approved one. Bill de Blasio, of course, would like one in New York. Seattle has been fighting to open one for years. The question is will any of these sites, if they're opened, open anywhere near the homes of the people who want to build them? The answer, of course, is no. But what is it like when one opens in your neighborhood? Jason Rantz is a radio host, and he joins us tonight. Jason, thanks very much for coming on. So, this is one of those ideas that's been discussed for many years that exists mostly in the realm of the theoretical. What happens when it becomes real? JASON RANTZ, THE JASON RANTZ SHOW HOST, AM 770 KTTH: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: What's the effect of one of these sites?

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: The - the effect is exactly what you probably think it is, which is, it has the capacity to ruin neighborhoods that went up to Vancouver and British Columbia. Happen to be there on vacation, and I decided, let me go to the heroin injection site area, and it's devastating. You see lots of people who are living out on the streets with addiction that's clearly not being treated. I saw, you know, a drug deal going down, when I was there, which apparently is not supposed to happen when you have these heroin injection sites. And it's - it's just sad. And the debate has been, at least here in Seattle, I'm assuming, in Denver soon, we don't want them necessarily in our neighborhoods.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It also is sad, I would think, for the acts (ph). By the way, this has been tried in Europe. I believe, this was tried in Switzerland 20 years ago, and it was stopped because it was too depressing. But doesn't it suggest that municipalities are kind of giving up on the people like we're not going to try you to - to convince you to stop using heroin and give you treatment. We're just going to let you do it until, I guess, you die. Is that what they're saying? What are they saying?

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: It - it's an unfortunate reality because when they first started to talk about it in Seattle it was about saving people, right? It was about helping people who were addicted to heroin.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: And then it started to become OK, well now it's just about making sure that when they do inject themselves with this deadly drug, they don't die of an overdose, which is something, you know, no one wants to see overdose deaths. I think--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Of course, not.

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: --in a lot of cases, some of these people's hearts are in the right place. But, you know, there's a group of people like myself who say, well, a really safe way to deal with this is to get the person off of heroin. We can offer treatment on demand, which is something that, you know, we have the money for. I'm in a state where the Governor who desperately wants to be President, he's not going to be, he suggested $1.1 Billion to save the Orcas in the Puget Sound. And saving the Orcas, very important, but he offered $30 million to deal with the opioid crisis, and it would feel more appropriate if maybe he switch those numbers around--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right. That's for sure.

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: --if you've got the money. Yes, human life to (ph) think is a little bit more valuable here.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, leaders are supposed to, need to care about the people they lead, or else, they can't lead effectively. Is there a parent in the world who upon finding out that his kid was using heroin, do you think would say, "You know what? I'm going to get you clean needles. You can shoot up in your bedroom. I can't stop you. But I just want you to inject safely at home?" Would any parents say that? Or would a parent instead say, "I'm going to do whatever I can to get you off it."

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: The people who don't have kids who are supportive of this will say that--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: --if they were a parent, and they were in that circumstance, they would. But when you talk to normal people, when you talk to the average everyday person--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: --of course, they don't want that to happen. And I feel like if we're not going to do that with our own kids, perhaps, we should not do that with other people's kids. I know it's difficult. I know that it is expensive. And I know that when people are addicted to heroin, you know, you - they have to be in a place where they feel ready to overcome that addiction. But something--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: --that gets in the way of feeling ready is handing them a needle to say, "Hey, shoot up here. We'll supervise it. And it's Seattle, so it's probably going to be a little bit crazier. We'll set the mood light rights. We'll - we'll have some like smooth jazz in the background," like that's just not an appropriate way to go about this. I would rather we spend focus our energy on actual services to save them to get them off of this drug.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Exactly. So nicely put. It is difficult. It is complicated. But that's what you do when you care, and when you don't care, you do exactly what they're doing now. They don't care. Do they?

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: It's a - it - I don't want to say none of them care, right? I think there's some people whose hearts are in the right place. But it does seem to be the more--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I bet that's true.

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: --lazy way. It's - it's just lazier. And I'm not - I've been trying to think about why some people support this, and I haven't really gotten a straight answer. There are some people who basically want to legalize heroin. It's a small group of people. But there are folks in this community who are fighting for heroin injection sites, who are of the opinion that you could live a normal life and have normal relationships and be basically a functioning addict. And I'm - I suppose that's certainly possible with - with some cases. But I don't think the risk is worth it. And so, you start talking to people, they just feel like, it seems like they don't want to offend someone, who's addicted.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: And they want to be there when you're ready, and it's a very emotional approach. Again, I appreciate the emotion behind it. It just doesn't work. And that's how the - the conversation weirdly (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: --again started, "We're saving people that it's OK." Well how many people are actually--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: --getting off of their addiction? And magically, there's no data that they can cite.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Exactly. Junkies don't feel anything. I know (ph), you can't be alive if you don't feel things. Jason, thank you. It was really smart and interesting and helpful. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: RANTZ
utterances.sentences: Thanks for having me.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Time for Final Exam. We have a pretty different kind of arrangement tonight, a special Husband versus Wife edition. Which member of the Duffy family will take home the commemorative Erik Wemple mug? Find out after the break.

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.sentences: FINAL EXAM.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Time now for Final Exam, where we pit contestants who follow the news against one another to see who's been paying the closest attention. We've got a double Special Edition of Final Exam. So, our (ph) two contenders this evening have married each other, not tonight, but years ago. Rachel Campos-Duffy is regularly here on Fox. Her husband is a Member of Congress from Wisconsin, Congressman Sean Duffy. And hopefully, this will strengthen rather than divide their union.

utterances.speaker: REP. SEAN PATRICK DUFFY, R-WIS.
utterances.sentences: I look forward, Tucker (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's great to see you.

utterances.speaker: RACHEL CAMPOS-DUFFY, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You're brave enough to do (ph)--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Good to see you too, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Evidently, we're ploughing new ground here.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I'm excited to be part of that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. Well we're excited too.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Now, you know the rules. But I'm going to repeat them for the sake of people watching at home. I'm going to ask the questions. The first contestant to buzz gets to answer the question. You must wait until I finish asking it in order to answer. You can answer once I acknowledge by saying your name. Each correct answer is worth one point. If you get it wrong, we detract a point, the cruel math of Final Exam. Best of five wins.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Are you ready?

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I'm ready.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Is there any way I win this Tucker. I mean I think we're not two (ph) so I really don't--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, there's - there's - there's literally no chance. And, by the way, winning doesn't--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Yes. Mean I won--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --actually get to a victory, yes, there you go (ph). That's another show, entirely.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I think it (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. So, according to the rules laid out by the National Game Show Commission, all of today's questions must be either about food or animals. We went with food. So, the first question, this is multiple choice, please listen carefully. President Trump says he doesn't care what lawmakers call the Border wall and ordered a food - offered a food-related suggestion. Which name did he suggest? Was it--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --A, quarter pounder with cheese, B, pancakes, C, peaches?

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: That sounds (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I think it goes by definition to your husband. I'm sorry. The Judge - the Judges have weighed in on this.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I'm going to go with C, peaches.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You're going to go with C? Is it peaches?

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD J. TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Whatever you want to call, it's OK with me. They can name it whatever they can. Name it peaches. I don't care what they name. But we need money. Peaches.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Peaches.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Peaches. You both knew that.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I did. And I thought the question was over (ph) by mistake.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You know you knew it too well. I think that's what it was.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: But she has to wait for - all multiple choice has to be--

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: OK. I got it. I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That is correct.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: --presented (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: All (ph) you have to - you have to wait till we finish asking the question. OK.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We'll - we can do it this time. I know.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Costco, the store, says it is sold out of a 27 tub of food that has a shelf life of 20 years. What type of food was it?

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Oh, that was not - that's not right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Rachel?

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I hit it first.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: It was macaroni and cheese.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Macaroni. I think you have to hold it down.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Oh, I - OK. I hit it first for sure.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It was macaroni and cheese. Is it macaroni and cheese?

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Everybody loves macaroni and cheese. But now you can get--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: How'd you know that?

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: --27 pounds of--

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: That's my voice. That's how I knew it. I did that.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: --with apparently has a shelf life--

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I did that commercial (ph).

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: --of 20 years.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: How many - how many children do you have?

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: We have eight.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. You need--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: OK. That's not fair.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --obviously, you need to invest in that.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Because that seem like a pretty good deal. I'm getting one myself.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I'm kind of a prepper (ph). Sounds like I'll do--

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: It--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: --I'll buy them (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You got to prepper (ph) it too.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: If it lasts for 20 years, so it can last--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Don't admit that on TV.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: --for our grandkids.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Remember, your official position on prepping is, "No, that's crazy."

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I do - I - I don't want to sound like that (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, no, God, no. You're like crazy (ph)--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Bit crazy.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --just to - OK. Question three, another multiple choice--

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --OK? A world record was set this week for the most liked Instagram photo ever. The picture doesn't feature a famous person or an exotic place. It has already nearly 50 million likes. It's a plain, boring photograph of what? A, a banana, B, a lemon, C, an egg?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Congressman.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I'm going to go with Kylie Jenner, I believe, and C, an egg. Didn't she tweet the egg out?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I have no idea.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Let's check it out.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But I'm not a Member of Congress. Is it C, the egg?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFEID MALE
utterances.sentences: World Record Egg. An account with that very name posted this single photo. It's a picture of an egg. The egg currently has 26 million likes and counting.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: How did that - I'm sorry. Either you live in this country--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --your whole life and you still don't understand it. What is that?

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: There must be like an Egg Commission that promotes eggs. They - they - they're getting a bonus. They're getting a bonus on this one.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: The Poultry Lobby is behind it. I mean, it's true (ph).

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: That's probably true.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You live in Washington, in other words (ph). Question four. One last multiple choice. Chaos--

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I'm - I'm winning it, right? It's two to one.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I'm not going to--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --it's not for me to keep score. Our viewers are watching. Chaos hit Flagstaff, Arizona on Monday when a tanker truck flipped over, spilling 3,500 gallons of which liquid all over the highway? Was it A, chocolate, B, coffee, C, beer?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Rachel.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Beer, C.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Was it C--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --beer?

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFEID MALE
utterances.sentences: 3,500 gallons. That's how much liquid chocolate spilled in Arizona--

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFEID MALE
utterances.sentences: --Interstate. A Chocolate River, they described it, forming after a tanker carrying it (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I thought it was beer too.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFEID MALE
utterances.sentences: --crashed.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I just took a guess.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You don't see (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I knew I was losing and I figured beer. Why would chocolate be on a truck?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You know what? You doubled down. And I, you know, I admire that.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Because and she's from Wisconsin. So, of course, she's thought beer.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I thought beer.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Of course, it's (ph) beer. She's not being like whatever (ph)--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: All right, final question. The Clemson Tigers, invited to the White House for a candlelit feast to celebrate their recent victory over Alabama, what type of food did the President serve the team?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Congressman Duffy.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I was there this morning. McDonald's, from the McDonald's that the food came from, I (ph) was there this morning.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Was it McDonald's?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We have pizzas. We have 300 hamburgers. Many, many French fries, all of our favorite foods. I want to see what's here when we leave, because I don't think it's going to be much.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: And Carlos (ph) owns the store.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And it wasn't - I just want to say, it wasn't exclusively, we're hearing from our Judges--

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: It's fast food.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --McDonald's. But McDonald's was represented.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So and - and our - and you're right. You still win because McDonald's--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: So then (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --it was McDonald's, Wendy's and what was the last one?

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I was going to say fast food.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Burger King. So it was an--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Burger King.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --it was an ecumenical sort of (ph).

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I - I just know that Carlos (ph) owns the McDonald's that gave the food to the White House where I saw (ph) this morning.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So impressive. Congressman, well first of all--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Look, it's been a shutdown. He's had a lot of time. I'm--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Exactly. But I would also say--

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: --I've been home with the kids.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It really is all a (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Of course, he knows.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --it's a shared victory. It's really a victory for your family. We're pro-family on this show.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Yes, we are (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, I'm going to award, in fact, our Erik Wemple commemorative mug to you, Rachel.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. That was great. Congratulations to you both.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: I'm - I'm truly honored.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Thank you. I went and watched the episode that you had with him on, it's great. YouTube it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It really - when I'm feeling sad, sometimes I pull it up, and it just--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: It makes you smile.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --just kind of lifts me up.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Or if you're on a shutdown--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Exactly, that's right.

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: --pull out (ph) the YouTube video.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's amazing. It's like Andy (ph).

utterances.speaker: CAMPOS-DUFFY
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Good, Tucker (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: All right, that's it for this week's Final Exam. Pay attention to the news all week. Come back Thursday to see if you can beat the experts. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well the hosts of The View are about the most rigid partisans on television, most of them anyway. You'll never hear them criticize anyone even faintly connected to the DNC Mothership. But today, they did go after a Democrat, believe it or not, Bill de Blasio of New York. Why'd they do that? Trace Gallagher has the story. Hey, Trace.

utterances.speaker: TRACE GALLAGHER, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Hi, Tucker. Mayor de Blasio was on The View for eight minutes, and used much of that time to boast about his progressive agenda, including his plan that New York City will guarantee healthcare for everyone, including hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants. As expected, except for Conservative Meghan McCain, de Blasio got very little resistance until Actress, Comedian and well-known Liberal, Whoopi Goldberg called the Mayor out about bike lanes in Manhattan. Watch.

utterances.speaker: WHOOPI GOLDBERG, THE VIEW CO-HOST, ABC
utterances.sentences: So, I like all of that. That all sounds good. You know what's really pissing me off?

utterances.speaker: MAYOR BILL DE BLASIO, NEW YORK CITY, NEW YORK
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Uh-oh.

utterances.speaker: DE BLASIO
utterances.sentences: I've never heard you pissed off before.

utterances.speaker: GOLDBERG
utterances.sentences: No, you actually haven't.

utterances.speaker: GOLDBERG
utterances.sentences: You've built 83 miles of protected bike lanes.

utterances.speaker: DE BLASIO
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: GOLDBERG
utterances.sentences: OK?

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.sentences: Goldberg's complaint is that adding bike lanes, which is being done by Liberal politicians across the country invariably leads to traffic gridlock. De Blasio defended himself saying, fewer car lanes means fewer fatalities. Watch.

utterances.speaker: DE BLASIO
utterances.sentences: Slow down the traffic.

utterances.speaker: GOLDBERG
utterances.sentences: But you've screwed the city up. Well it's not--

utterances.speaker: DE BLASIO
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GOLDBERG
utterances.sentences: --just - wait but--

utterances.speaker: DE BLASIO
utterances.sentences: No, listen, listen--

utterances.speaker: GOLDBERG
utterances.sentences: --once you (ph) listen--

utterances.speaker: DE BLASIO
utterances.sentences: --they've made it safer.

utterances.speaker: GOLDBERG
utterances.sentences: --you're going through the city with a - with a police escort. I come in every day.

utterances.speaker: GOLDBERG
utterances.sentences: I - I come in every day.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We come (ph).

utterances.speaker: GOLDBERG
utterances.sentences: And I find that because you can't make a turn anywhere, you can't go straight anywhere. When there is a storm, people can't move anywhere.

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.sentences: You didn't hear it there. But the audience also turned against the Mayor. Finally, de Blasio was asked if he's running for President in 2020, and he dodged the question. Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Trace Gallagher, thank you. I just appreciate the increase in public urination--

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --since he's been in office. It's great.

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.sentences: TECH TYRANNY.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well you probably know by now that your smartphone has a lot of functions, and one of them is to spy on you full-time on your personal life. But it's not just tech companies who are tracking your every move. It turns out they're selling that data to other people. So now, it's possible for virtually anybody to know everywhere that you go without your knowledge, and get rich from it. Brett Larson is an Anchor at Fox News Headlines 24/7. He's been investigating this for us, and he joins us tonight. Hey, Brett. BRETT LARSON, ANCHOR, FOX NEWS HEADLINES 24/7: Hey, Tucker. It is yet another tale of the technology we love, and have come to rely on, turning over sensitive information without our consent. So, when your cell phone is on, it is in constant communication with nearby cell towers. That way, when you get a call or text or open up an email, the signal you need is right there. One slight issue. That data is collected by the mobile operators. And it turns out, some of them have been selling it, and not to law enforcement, but a variety of companies like bail bondsmen, car dealers, even emergency roadside assistance. But some of these companies that get the data, they may be turning around and selling it again, which means if you've got someone's cell number and some money, you could potentially find out in real-time where that phone is. Now, this isn't anything new. Last year, there were some grumblings on Capitol Hill. Oregon Senator, Ron Wyden, sent letters to the wireless providers and the FCC to get the situation under control. There was a flurry of responses from the wireless providers saying they'd put a stop to it. But here we are in 2019, and it's still happening. An example from just last week, from online site Motherboard, they found that with a little cash and a phone number, they were able to get location information of a user's phone. Within a few days of the report, all the major wireless carriers said they have stopped or they will stop selling your data with a few exceptions like those for safety reasons, and roadside assistance. So, probably nothing's going to change for now.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. It seems to be following (ph) to Ron Wyden, of all people.

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And good for him to keep abreast of this. So, let me just ask a dumb question.

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: When you sign up for one of these phones, buy it, get the plan--

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --is there any indication - is there any way to know, if you're an average person with bad eyesight that they're going to be selling your data?

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: There is no way to know. And all of this stuff, so far, has not been an opt-in situation. You're not getting a message that says, "Hey, we're about to tell somebody exactly where your phone is. Are you OK with this?" And all the wireless companies have said, "Oh, yes, yes. We're - they're supposed to be doing that. And if they're not doing it, they're in violation of our agreement." But they're still selling - they're still selling the data, and people can still get their hands on it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I don't know why I'm laughing. It's - it's horrifying. And I'm--

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: It is horrifying. You seem to be (ph) laughing. But it's that horrifying like--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --it is horrifying.

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: --oh, my gosh, what like what do we have to--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: --do to make this stop.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's worse than you think it is always.

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Thanks for proving that. Brett Larson, great to see you.

utterances.speaker: LARSON
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Tucker. Good to be here.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We're out of time tonight. We'll be back tomorrow night, 8:00 P.M., the show that's the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness, and groupthink. But don't fret. We have good news for you. Four seconds early, we're turning over to our friend Sean Hannity live from New York. Content and Programming Copyright 2019 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
